block.comment: This block tells the Arduino which analog pin to use to use for sending data to the pixels. The analog pins are usually labeled with A1, A2, A2, etc.
This block creates a list of colors. The size determines how many colors are in the list.

The setup block runs after all library blocks. It only runs once.
Use a setup block initialize variables in code.
This block sets the value the variable is storing. This variable will store color only.

A for "count with block" creates a loop where it will stop looping once the variable has reached the "to" point. The best way to learn this block is to drag it out and play around with its values in the simulator.
This block puts a color into the list. The position determines where in the list the color will be. The first color in the list starts at position 1.
This block gets the value that the variable is storing. This variable store a number.

A for "count with block" creates a loop where it will stop looping once the variable has reached the "to" point. The best way to learn this block is to drag it out and play around with its values in the simulator.
This block puts a color into the list. The position determines where in the list the color will be. The first color in the list starts at position 1.
This block gets the value that the variable is storing. This variable store a number.

A for "count with block" creates a loop where it will stop looping once the variable has reached the "to" point. The best way to learn this block is to drag it out and play around with its values in the simulator.
This block puts a color into the list. The position determines where in the list the color will be. The first color in the list starts at position 1.
This block gets the value that the variable is storing. This variable store a number.

A for "count with block" creates a loop where it will stop looping once the variable has reached the "to" point. The best way to learn this block is to drag it out and play around with its values in the simulator.
This block puts a color into the list. The position determines where in the list the color will be. The first color in the list starts at position 1.
This block gets the value that the variable is storing. This variable store a number.

A for "count with block" creates a loop where it will stop looping once the variable has reached the "to" point. The best way to learn this block is to drag it out and play around with its values in the simulator.
This block puts a color into the list. The position determines where in the list the color will be. The first color in the list starts at position 1.
This block gets the value that the variable is storing. This variable store a number.

The loop block runs on repeat until your Arduino loses power. It runs right after your setup block if you have one.
If you are using the simulator, you can control how many times it repeats.

A for "count with block" creates a loop where it will stop looping once the variable has reached the "to" point. The best way to learn this block is to drag it out and play around with its values in the simulator.
This block will set the color of one led in your fastled light strip. This block uses 1 as the first pixel.
This block gets the value that the variable is storing. This variable store a number.
This block gets a color from the list. The position determines where in the list you are getting the color. The first color in the list starts at position 1.
This block gets the value that the variable is storing. This variable store a number.
Use the block to display all RGB LED Strips
This block pauses the Arduino for x number of seconds. Nothing will be able to be sensed while the delay is running.
This block sets the value the variable is storing. This variable will store color only.
This block gets a color from the list. The position determines where in the list you are getting the color. The first color in the list starts at position 1.
